newsitem.title: USA: AT&T says CEO 1996 compensation down 14 pct.
newsitem.headline: AT&T says CEO 1996 compensation down 14 pct.

text.p: AT&T Corp.'s outgoing Chairman Robert Allen took a 14 percent pay cut for 1996 -- to nearly $5.5 million from about $6.4 million in 1995 -- largely due to the lackluster performance of AT&T stock, the telecommunications giant said Tuesday.
Allen's compensation package, determined by AT&T board members, also contained no stock options or restricted stock grants, the company said in its 1997 proxy statement.

In contrast, Allen received stock options in 1995 estimated at the time to be worth up to $11 million based on certain stock performance goals, making his total pay package worth as much as $16 million.

The denial of stock options and the reduction in Allen's 1996 compensation package to nearly $5.5 million from about $6.4 million in 1995 reflected the decline in AT&T stock, company spokeswoman Eileen Connolly said.
"Clearly, the main decrease from the committee's vantage point is the reduction in shareowner value over the course of the year as represented by the stock price," she said.

The value of AT&T-related holdings of the company's shareholders fell 9 percent in 1996, while the S&P 500 index rose 20 percent, the board's executive compensation committee found, according to the proxy statement.

Allen's rich pay package came under fire at AT&T's annual meeting in April 1996 from shareholder activists, employees and union officials who criticized Allen for receiving the award at a time he was leading a drive to slash 40,000 jobs from AT&T and its subsidaries.
Despite the ruckus raised over Allen's 1995 pay package, AT&T's Connolly noted that the options remain valueless at the current stock price.
Allen is slated to leave his seat as chairman and chief executive to the current chief operating officer, John Walter, in 1998.

Allen's total 1996 compensation included an 18 percent reduction in his bonus to about $1.3 million from $1.5 million the previous year. The bonus was about 25 percent lower than the target level of $1.7 million, Connolly said.
The proxy cited lower-than-expected earnings due to poor performance in its long-distance and credit card businesses and slashing capital spending as additional factors in the reduced pay package.

AT&T shares edged up 12.5 cents to $34.875 on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock, which traded above $48 in January 1996, has since fallen nearly 30 percent amid growing competition in its core long-distance market.
